units.title: Integrate single-cell transcriptomics and Visium data
units.text: After integrating single-cell transcriptomics and Visium data using our recently developed cell2location algorithm18, cell states were mapped to the endometrium and/or the myometrium.
units.rationale: This is an actionable computational step that defines a protocol for spatial mapping of cell states using specific tools.

units.title: Classify epithelial cells into four main groups
units.text: Epithelial cells are classified into four main groups based on their marker expression: (1) SOX9 populations, enriched in the proliferative phase and expressing genes characteristic of rising estrogen levels (MMP7, ESR1); (2) ciliated cells (PIFO, TPPP3); (3) lumenal cells (LGR5); and (4) glandular cells (SCGB2A2) (Fig. 2b–d and Extended Data Fig. 4a,b).
units.rationale: This provides a clear, marker-based classification protocol for epithelial cell subtypes.

units.title: Define spatial coordinates of SOX9 subsets
units.text: By integrating scRNA-seq and Visium data (Fig. 2e and Extended Data Fig. 4c), we define specific spatial coordinates for these SOX9 subsets: (1) noncycling SOX9+LGR5+ cells are enriched in the surface epithelium; (2) noncycling SOX9+LGR5− cells are located in the basal glands; and (3) cycling SOX9+ cells map to glands in the regenerating superficial layer.
units.rationale: This describes a protocol for assigning spatial localization to specific cell subpopulations using integrated data.

units.title: Validate marker expression with smFISH
units.text: Single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization (smFISH) with RNAscope probes shows higher expression of the proliferative marker MKI67 in the superficial layer of the endometrium during the proliferative phase, validating Visium data (Extended Data Fig. 5a).
units.rationale: This is a validated experimental protocol to confirm spatial gene expression patterns observed computationally.

units.title: Profile endometrial organoids at single-cell resolution
units.text: We profile three-dimensional endometrial organoids at single-cell resolution to characterize their hormonal responses in vitro and design a computational toolkit to compare the results with those observed in vivo to benchmark this model system.
units.rationale: This outlines a protocol for using organoids to model hormonal responses and validate findings against in vivo data.

units.title: Modulate WNT and NOTCH pathways in organoid cultures
units.text: Finally, by modulating WNT and NOTCH pathways in the organoid cultures, we develop lineage-specific endometrial epithelial cells and define the molecular events involved in their response to ovarian hormones.
units.rationale: This describes a controlled experimental protocol to manipulate signaling pathways and observe lineage-specific outcomes.

units.title: Integrate scRNA-seq and snRNA-seq datasets
units.text: To generate a cellular map of the human endometrium that accounts for the temporal and spatial changes across the menstrual cycle, uterine samples were analyzed by single-cell transcriptomics—single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and single-nucleus RNA sequencing (snRNA-seq)—alongside spatial transcriptomics methods (10x Genomics Visium slides and high-resolution microscopy) (Fig. 1a and Extended Data Fig. 1a).
units.rationale: This defines a protocol for combining multiple transcriptomic modalities to build a comprehensive cellular map.

units.title: Assign cell identity using known marker expression
units.text: We identify 14 clusters that were assigned cell identity based on their expression of known markers (Extended Data Fig. 1g).
units.rationale: This is a standard protocol step for annotating cell clusters using established biomarkers.

units.title: Subcluster immune populations to resolve heterogeneity
units.text: Subclustering of immune cells resolves their heterogeneity, including identification of the three uterine natural killer cells (uNK1, uNK2, uNK3), dendritic cells (DCs), macrophages (uM1, uM2), and other immune subsets.
units.rationale: This describes a protocol for resolving immune cell diversity through hierarchical clustering and annotation.

units.title: Analyze epithelial lineage differentiation across menstrual phases
units.text: We next focused on the two main lineages of endometrial epithelial cells, secretory and ciliated, across the menstrual cycle and analyzed these subsets individually (Fig. 2a).
units.rationale: This outlines a protocol for temporal analysis of epithelial lineage dynamics across menstrual phases.
